summary: The text discusses the lamentation over the ruin of the earthly Jerusalem and its people, extending this grief to the present church's losses. It also considers the fall of those from both the old and new people who have departed from faith, and the plight of individual souls. The lamentations cover both past and future events, reflecting on present sufferings as well as historical and future captivities. It emphasizes learning to lament personal faults by considering the community's shared grief. The text explains how the lamentation is organized in four-part structures, reflecting the composition of the world from the four elements. The prophetic mourning encompasses a wide view of history, highlighting the continuity of grief from historical figures such as King Josiah to prophecies made by Jeremiah.
